messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Terry Smithwick <Tinyallen@...>
wrote:

> QS is a phonemic tool that could potentially
> inscribe most versions of each English word into a
> very small set of similar written words. This is a
> fine and noble goal, but it relies on a carefully
> controlled amount of deliberate imprecision.

A lot of posts have stated just your sentiment. Maybe I was too sloppy
in my wording of my original suggestion. QS does not have to have the
precision of IPA, not by any means. On the other hand, I thought it
would help to say that #34 is the back most, most closed, rounded
vowel (as Read seems to have intended it), rather than saying it
sounds like Ox. Since you and I don't distinguish between #34 and #33,
how is that helpful to say what it sounds like? On the other hand, my
approach has problems, I admit. (See below).

>
> Ideally, with QS we could be just as phonemic as
> Spanish, by accommodating just as many dialects.

Yes, that is the realization I am coming to. We don't want to
introduce new letters into QS to accomodate dialects, since such an
approach would make it less useful than TO by far.

> I'm one of those for whom 'calm', 'haul' and 'on'
> sound identical; *my* version of QS-IPA would not
> resemble that of someone who can distinguish between
> any pair of these. But I could learn that certain
> common words should be spelled a certain way, if I
> ever needed to.

Well, I think your dialect would correspond to the IPA. You would
determine which of the three sounds you actually use, and just use
that one. But then, how do we express the completely different vowels
expressed, say, in Australia?

So I think you are advocating a somewhat standardized spelling? Many
people are against a standarized spelling in QS, but we should at
least keep in mind that standardizion in QS would be about 10 times
easier than standardization in TO. (I just love words like
"phychology" and "embarrass." It's only taken me 30 years to learn how
to spell them right.)

>
> Wasn't there another proposal for a simplified
> alphabet that merged similar sounds together to reduce
> the number of characters?

I am new, so I can't say. But my understanding at this point is that
wouldn't be a good idea, either. For example, Anthony Grahn makes the
distinction between "tot" and "taught" in his speech. I don't. If we
took away #34 (totally useless to me), we force Anthony to have to
merge sounds just because I do. Which, come to think of it, is a good
idea, since I think everyone should speak like me! Ha ha.

Paul
